title: Automated License Plate Readers (La Habra Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Automated License Plate Readers (La Habra Police Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Custodian of Records:

This letter constitutes a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, submitted with the assistance of MuckRock News. 

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.

A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.
The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  

Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records:  

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 
A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents  that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.
A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods January 1, 2021 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)

B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2021.
B2.  The aggregate number of “hits” during 2021.
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days. 
B4.  The aggregate number of “hits” from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information  is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.

Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations. 

We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act

C1. A description of  the information technology and physical location in which the records exist.
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and 
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought.

Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a list below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records. 

American Canyon Police Department
Auburn Police Department
Bakersfield Police Department
Beaumont Police Department
Bell Gardens Police Department
Bell Police Department
Belvedere Police Department
Beverly Hills Police Department
Brawley Police Department
Brentwood Police Department

Hermosa Beach Police Department
Imperial Police Department

La Verne Police Department
Laguna Beach Police Department
Livermore Police Department

Westminster Police Department

Yolo County Sheriff's Office
(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set ) 

CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs.

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.
                                               
Sincerely,
 
 
Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

title: Incident report -- sheriff's deputy accidental discharge

communications.subject: Florida Sunshine Law Request: Incident report -- sheriff's deputy accidental discharge
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Florida Sunshine Law, I hereby request the following records:

The incident report for the accidental discharge of a sheriff's deputy weapon at Treasure Coast Classical Academy in Stuart on Monday September 19, 2022.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Russel Neiss

title: Automated License Plate Readers (San Mateo Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Automated License Plate Readers (San Mateo Police Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Custodian of Records:

This letter constitutes a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, submitted with the assistance of MuckRock News. 

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.

A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.
The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  

Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records:  

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 
A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents  that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.
A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods January 1, 2021 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)

B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2021.
B2.  The aggregate number of “hits” during 2021.
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days. 
B4.  The aggregate number of “hits” from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information  is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.

Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations. 

We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act

C1. A description of  the information technology and physical location in which the records exist.
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and 
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought.

Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a list below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records.

CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs.

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.
                                               
Sincerely,
 
 
Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days.
B4. The aggregate number of “hits” from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality. As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.

Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations.

We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act

C1. A description of the information technology and physical location in which the records exist.
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought.

Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a list below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records.

(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set )

CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records.

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request.

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs.

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.

Sincerely,

Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

title: Kent School financial records

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: Kent School financial records
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Washington Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

The following financial records for all schools under the authority of the school district:
- Acquaintance Roll (or salary and employment information by any other name)
- The Cash Book (or record of all financial transactions by any other name, specifically including COVID relief funds accounting)
- Contingencies Register
- Fee Collection Register
- Register of Donations Received
- Register of Scholarships
- Budget records for the last 5 years

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Josh Dukes

communications.subject: 22-23-19 Dukes
communications.communication:
Good Afternoon,

Please see Kent School District's clarifying questions to your request.


The following financial records for all schools under the authority of the school district:
- Acquaintance Roll (or salary and employment information by any other name)

KSD Comment:  "Acquaintance Roll" is not a term we are familiar with.  We can help present salary information, as we have access to that.  Clarification would be good:

  *   Would they require amounts in aggregate for the year, or individual monthly pay?
     *   What is the objective?  If simply overall pay, we might suggest information in the aggregate.
     *   Does the information need to be broken down by person?
     *   Payroll information can be quite nebulous, with many different categories of pay, deductions, and expenses.  Are they needing that much detail?
  *   What time periods are they requesting?

- The Cash Book (or record of all financial transactions by any other name, specifically including COVID relief funds accounting)

KSD Comment:  "Cash Book" is not a term we are familiar with.  We could provide information on all cash we have received, if this is what is being requested, but this can be very detailed.  Also, is money going out a part of this request?  Clarification would be good:

  *   For money in -- Do they require the information by each party paying us or would they like to see the information by types of cash received (revenue types in the aggregate)?
  *   Revenue in the aggregate would take much less time than information by individuals.
  *   For money out - are they looking for more than just an aggregation?  If detailed transactions were needed, this data would be voluminous.  One can imagine if $450 million is spent each year, how voluminous this might be; i.e., millions of transactions, possibly.
  *   What time periods are they requesting?
  *   COVID relief fund accounting is not too much of a burden, but do they want that down to the transaction level, or in the aggregate?

- Contingencies Register

Are you looking for what obligations we may have in the future to pay, we could interpret this as what we call "encumbrances" or are you looking for what we call "accounts payable".  Accounts payable information is what is owed to vendors and can be provided by vendor name, or in the aggregate, by the type of payment.  Further clarification is definitely needed here.

  *   What time period is being requested?

- Fee Collection Register

We would surmise this would be a published list of what fees we are charging our students for education, is this interpretation correct? Additionally, what time period is being requested?

- Register of Donations Received

Do you want this by person and individual instance, or in the aggregate?  In addition, this could be considered part of the "Cash Book" request.

  *   What time period is being requested?



- Register of Scholarships

Are you interested in what activity there has been for scholarships we manage; i.e., money received and disbursed?

  *   What time period is being requested?

- Budget records for the last 5 years

This is very nebulous and further clarification is needed,  Literally, every record generated from a finance standpoint has to do with budget. Please clarify why type of  budget records you are seeking.



Sincerely,

[cid:image001.png@01D8C778.DE4AB2F0]<https://us-east-2.protection.sophos.com/?d=kent.k12.wa.us&u=aHR0cDovL3d3dy5rZW50LmsxMi53YS51cy8=&e=bGJyYXppbGVAa3Vvdy5vcmc=&h=d6ef8f34c41045f7a123e0f865a2f995&t=bnZCSVU5eEZ0Uy9VSlJ3eG5kU3VUdFBSN3NqWFl3MXBHQ2ZYWVBRMUhVRT0=>
Tyler Inboden (She/Her)
Public Records Officer

communications.subject: RE: Washington Public Records Act Request: Kent School financial records
communications.communication:
Answers inline

> * Would they require amounts in aggregate for the year, or individual monthly pay?

Individual monthly pay, in CSV, XLS, or other tabular format if export is required. If I have a tabular format I can aggregate and group as needed.

> * Does the information need to be broken down by person?

Yes.

> * Payroll information can be quite nebulous, with many different categories of pay, deductions, and expenses. Are they needing that much detail?

Yes.

> * What time periods are they requesting?

I would like 5 years, but I will accept 2 years if there is a significant increase in difficulty to fulfill a request going back that far.


> KSD Comment: "Cash Book" is not a term we are familiar with. We could provide information on all cash we have received, if this is what is being requested, but this can be very detailed.

Perfect. Please provide in a tabular format, CSV, XLS, if export is required. 

> Also, is money going out a part of this request?

Yes.

> * For money in -- Do they require the information by each party paying us or would they like to see the information by types of cash received (revenue types in the aggregate)?
> * Revenue in the aggregate would take much less time than information by individuals.

Please provide aggregate records.

> * For money out - are they looking for more than just an aggregation? If detailed transactions were needed, this data would be voluminous. One can imagine if $450 million is spent each year, how voluminous this might be; i.e., millions of transactions, possibly.

A few million records is not an especially large data set for me.

> * What time periods are they requesting?

5 years if possible, but I will accept 2 years if 5 years will add a significant delay for the response.

> * COVID relief fund accounting is not too much of a burden, but do they want that down to the transaction level, or in the aggregate?

Transaction.

> Are you looking for what obligations we may have in the future to pay, we could interpret this as what we call "encumbrances" or are you looking for what we call "accounts payable". Accounts payable information is what is owed to vendors and can be provided by vendor name, or in the aggregate, by the type of payment. Further clarification is definitely needed here.

Both at the individual level, in a tabular format if export is required.

* What time period is being requested?

5 years, but I will accept 2 years if 5 years adds a significant delay.

> We would surmise this would be a published list of what fees we are charging our students for education, is this interpretation correct?

Yes.

> Additionally, what time period is being requested?

Same answer as above for the same question.

> - Register of Donations Received

> Do you want this by person and individual instance, or in the aggregate? In addition, this could be considered part of the "Cash Book" request.

If this is included in the "Cash Book" I can pull the records from there.

> * What time period is being requested?

Same answer as above for the same question.

> - Register of Scholarships

> Are you interested in what activity there has been for scholarships we manage; i.e., money received and disbursed?

Yes.

> * What time period is being requested?

See above.

> - Budget records for the last 5 years

> This is very nebulous and further clarification is needed, Literally, every record generated from a finance standpoint has to do with budget. Please clarify why type of budget records you are seeking.

This would be budget planning and reports tracking progress on that plan.

I would also like all statements of work and purchase orders with outside vendors where those exist in digital format.

2021-2022

2015-2015

Additionally, Our server is unable to produce electronic records of "cash out" with the scope provided. (See highlighted text below from when we asked for clarification).  Our system is erroring out and won't produce the report after 3 hours of processing time.

Is it possible to narrow this down to manageable chunks, otherwise, we'd have to go to paper on this item, which would plainly be over 500 pages - we would guess it could be a million pages; i.e., a document for every cash out transaction.


> * For money out - are they looking for more than just an aggregation? If detailed transactions were needed, this data would be voluminous. One can imagine if $450 million is spent each year, how voluminous this might be; i.e., millions of transactions, possibly.

5 years if possible, but I will accept 2 years if 5 years will add a significant delay for the response.

However, we can produce a summary of accounts with cash out that can be shared electronically, if that would be sufficient?

At this time we are still processing your request, please expect your next installment on or around November 29th, 2022.

Please see the attached responsive records to include the expenditure records requested including the Covid data.

Additionally,  we are following up on this: Our server is unable to produce electronic records of "cash out" with the scope provided. (See highlighted text below from when we asked for clarification).  Our system is erroring out and won't produce the report after 3 hours of processing time.

Is it possible to narrow this down to manageable chunks, otherwise, we'd have to go to paper on this item, which would plainly be over 500 pages - we would guess it could be a million pages; i.e., a document for every cash out transaction.


> * For money out - are they looking for more than just an aggregation? If detailed transactions were needed, this data would be voluminous. One can imagine if $450 million is spent each year, how voluminous this might be; i.e., millions of transactions, possibly.

A few million records is not an especially large data set for me.

> * What time periods are they requesting?

5 years if possible, but I will accept 2 years if 5 years will add a significant delay for the response.

However, we can produce a summary of accounts with cash out that can be shared electronically, if that would be sufficient?

At this time we are still processing your request, please expect your next installment on or around December 16th, 2022.

Sincerely,

title: APHIS African Swine Fever

communications.subject: Freedom of Information Act Request: APHIS African Swine Fever
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Freedom of Information Act, I hereby request the following records:

Any and all reports, memos, white papers or other documents outlining APHIS's strategy for preventing the emergence of African Swine Fever within the United States. 

I am a reporter for The Guardian and other outlets.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 20 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Jimmy Tobias

communications.communication:
Good afternoon Mr. Tobias,

Thank you for taking the time to speak earlier regarding your request. Per our conversation, below is the drafted language for your revised request. Please take a look at it and let me know if this language is acceptable, or if you have any additional revisions that would better capture your request:

"Request seeking records concerning APHIS's response to the emergence of African Swine Fever in the United States: Specifically, any current or proposed action plans for addressing ASF in the United States, and any documents outlining or detailing APHIS's ASF strategy. Additionally, a list of APHIS personnel involved in the development of such an action plan or strategy outline. The date range for this request is 1/1/20 to 11/4/21".

I took the liberty of applying a date range for your request of 1/1/20 to todays' date; my thinking was that roughly two years should capture any current action plans or strategy outlines, but please let me know if that needs to be revised.

If this language works for you, I'll send your revised request to our intake team today, and they will send you a formal receipt acknowledgment and FOIA request tracking number from them shortly, either tomorrow or first thing next week. We'll then refer your request to the appropriate personnel to conduct a search of their records for documents responsive to your request, and I will be in touch as soon as they have completed their search, with an estimate on how long it should take me to complete my review.

Thank you again very much for your assistance, and again please don't hesitate to contact me if you have any questions at all.
Best,


Hamilton Kuralt
Government Information Specialist
U.S. Department of Agriculture
Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service
Freedom of Information Act & Privacy Act
Unit 50, Section 2B-03.3
4700 River Road, Riverdale, MD 20737

title: [Rutherford, NJ] Gavin McInnes cancellation

communications.subject: New Jersey Open Public Records Act Request: [Rutherford, NJ] Gavin McInnes cancellation
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the New Jersey Open Public Records Act, I hereby request the following records:

1) Any emails, text messages, social media messages, or other communications sent to or from Mayor Frank Nunziato, Police Chief John Russo, Borough Administrator Robert Kakolewski, or Councilmember Maria Begg-Roberson between November 1, 2022 and November 11, 2022, containing any of the following terms:

a) "McInnes"
b) "Proud Boys"
c) "Cognitive Dissidents"
d) "Williams Center"

This request specifically seeks records sent, received, or held by the named officials, regardless of whether the device, system, or network on which the records were sent, received, or stored is owned, leased, or otherwise controlled by the Borough of Rutherford.

2) Any police logs, incident reports, or other records concerning the cancelled "Cognitive Dissidents" event.

3) Any police records generated between November 1, 2022 and November 11, 2022, containing any of the terms identified in Request No. 1.

4) Any communications, or records referencing communications, between the Borough of Rutherford and the Williams Center (or its representatives) concerning the "Cognitive Dissidents" event.

5) Any communications, or records referencing communications, between the Borough of Rutherford and Gavin McInnes concerning the "Cognitive Dissidents" event.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 7 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Adam Steinbaugh

title: Automated License Plate Readers (Chula Vista Police Department)

communications.subject: California Public Records Act Request: Automated License Plate Readers (Chula Vista Police Department)
communications.communication:
Dear Custodian of Records:

This letter constitutes a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, submitted with the assistance of MuckRock News. 

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency").

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing.

A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data;
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data;
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information;
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information.
The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  

Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records:  

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 
A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents  that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data.
A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods January 1, 2021 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist)

B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2021.
B2.  The aggregate number of “hits” during 2021.
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days. 
B4.  The aggregate number of “hits” from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period.

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information  is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality.  As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software.

Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations. 

We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act

C1. A description of  the information technology and physical location in which the records exist.
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and 
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought.

Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a list below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records. 

American Canyon Police Department
Auburn Police Department

(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set ) 

CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs.

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs.

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109.
                                               
Sincerely,
 
 
Dave Maass
Director of Investigations
Electronic Frontier Foundation

communications.communication:
Dear Dave, Thank you for your request for public records from the City of Chula Vista Police Department. Your request was received on 11/6/2022 and assigned Request No. P000140-110622 for tracking purposes.  Your request has been forwarded to the appropriate department(s) to locate the document(s) you are requesting.  We will respond to your request within 10 days as required under the California Public Records Act (GC 6250 et seq.). You can monitor the progress of your request by logging into My Request Center on the Portal. Thank you for using the Chula Vista's City Public Records Center. Thank you, 
 City of Chula Vista Police Department

communications.subject: [Records Center] PD Records Request :: P000140-110622
communications.communication:
--- Please respond above this line --- 

 
RE: PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST of November 06, 2022., Reference # P000140-110622. 
Dear Dave Maass, 
The City of Chula Vista is in receipt of your November 06, 2022 request for the following public records pursuant to the California Public Records Act (“CPRA”) (Cal. Gov. Code section 6250 et seq.): "Dear Custodian of Records: 

This letter constitutes a request under the California Public Records Act ("CPRA") from the Electronic Frontier Foundation, submitted with the assistance of MuckRock News. 

We request the following records related to Automated License Plate Readers ("ALPRs") and your law enforcement agency ("Agency"). 

Part A - Information related to ALPR data sharing. 

A1. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares ALPR data; 
A2. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives ALPR data; 
A3. The names of agencies and organizations with which the Agency shares “hot list” information; 
A4. The names of agencies and organizations from which the Agency receives “hot list” information. 
The information requested in items A1-A4 is readily available for extraction through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Data Sharing Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality. 

Most agencies have encountered little difficulty in providing this information (see below). In a small number of cases, an agency has interpreted items A1-A4 as requesting the creation of a record that does not exist. We disagree: this data is maintained by your software, can be exported through software your agency has already purchased, and is therefore subject to CPRA. 

However, should you disagree, you may alternatively produce the following records: 

A5. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that external agencies have signed to comply with Sec 1798.90.52(b) for accessing your agency's ALPR data. These documents are also often required under the "Releasing ALPR Data" subsection of a California law enforcement agency's SB 34 policy. 
A6. All agreements, memoranda of understanding, requests, or other certifying documents that your agency has signed pursuant to Sec 1798.90.52(b) to access other agencies' ALPR data. 
A7. All "records of access" required by Sec. 1798.90.52(a) for the periods January 1, 2021 until the date of processing this request. 

Items A5-A7 are not necessary if your agency provides the information requested in items A1-A4. We feel that items A1-A4 are more focused and would require less labor from your agency to produce. 

Part B - Information Related to Numbers of “Detections” (plate scans) and “Hits” (plate scans that matched to a hotlist) 

B1. The aggregate number of "detections" collected during 2021. 
B2. The aggregate number of “hits” during 2021. 
B3. The aggregate number of "detections" from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. For example, most Flock Safety systems may not have this data beyond 30 days. 
B4. The aggregate number of “hits” from January 1, 2022 until the date this request is processed. If your agency has a retention period shorter than 1 year, please provide whatever data is available based on your retention period. 

The information requested in items B1-B4 is readily available through the ALPR software you use. For example, with Vigilant Solutions/Motorola Solutions, this data can be exported easily using the Hit Ratio Report function. With Flock Safety, this information is available through the transparency portal function. Other software, such as BOSS, has similar functionality. As noted above, this information exists within your system and can be easily exported with existing software. 

Part C - Assistance, Description, and Recommendations. 

We make the following requests under section 6253.1 of the California Public Records Act 

C1. A description of the information technology and physical location in which the records exist. 
C2. Assist us identifying records and information that will help the public understand how ALPR data and hotlists are shared, how much data is collected year-to-year, and how much of that data matches a hot list; and 
C3. Provide suggestions for overcoming any practical basis for denying access to the information sought. 

Please note that more than 80 California law enforcement agencies have provided the information requested in Parts A1-A4 and B1-B4 in previous years. For your reference we have included a list below with the names of the agencies that have historically provided these records. 

American Canyon Police Department 
Auburn Police Department 
Bakersfield Police Department 
Beaumont Police Department 
Bell Gardens Police Department 
Bell Police Department 
Belvedere Police Department

Brawley Police Department

Fullerton Police Department

Hermosa Beach Police Department

La Mesa Police Department

Long Beach Police Department 
Marin County Sheriff's Office

Merced Police Department

Monterey Park Police Department

Oakley Police Department 
Orange County Sheriff's Office 
Orange Police Department 
Palm Springs Police Department 
Palos Verdes Estates Police 
Pasadena Police Department 
Pleasant Hill Police Department 
Pomona Police Department 
Redlands Police Department 
Redondo Beach Police Department 
Ripon Police Department 
Roseville Police Department 
Salinas Police Department 
San Bernardino County Sheriff's Office 
San Diego County Sheriff's Office 
San Diego Police Department 
San Mateo County Sheriff's Office 
Sausalito Police Department 
Simi Valley Police Department 
Stanislaus County Sheriff's Office 
Stockton Police Department 
Tiburon Police Department 
Torrance Police Department 
Tracy Police Department 
Tustin Police Department 
West Sacramento Police Department 
Westminster Police Department 
Woodland Police Department 
Yolo County Sheriff's Office 
(This URL links to a dataset with links to the records: https://www.eff.org/document/data-driven-2-california-dragnet-data-set ) 

CPRA requires you to undertake reasonable efforts to locate responsive records and to work in good faith with requesters to respond to their request. See CYAC v. City of National City, 220 Cal.App.4th 1385, 1430 (2013). Thus under the CPRA you are obligated to conduct a reasonable search and cannot deny a request merely because it might generate a large volume of records. 

We ask that you please respond to this request within 10 days either by providing all the requested records or by providing a written response setting forth the legal authority on which you rely in withholding or redacting any document, as well as stating when documents will be made available. Should you choose to withhold or reject this request, we ask that you provide an explanation of why your agency is responding differently compared to the many others that have complied with our request. 

We also request that any records maintained in an electronic format be provided in that same format (such as a PDF, CSV or XLS file), to avoid copying costs. 

However, should you be unable to do so, EFF will reimburse you for the direct costs of copying these records (if you elect to charge for copying) plus postage. If you anticipate that these costs will exceed $25.00, or that the time needed to copy the records will delay their release, please contact me so that I can arrange to inspect the documents or decide which documents I wish to have copied. Please also provide an invoice and a cost breakdown of the fee estimate. If the fees are less than $25.00, please copy and send the records and invoice as soon as possible, and we will promptly pay the required costs. 

Thank you for your consideration of this request. If you have any questions or concerns, or if I can provide any clarification that will help identify responsive documents or focus this request, please do not hesitate to contact me at (415) 436-9333 x151 or dm@eff.org. You may also mail correspondence to the Electronic Frontier Foundation, 815 Eddy. St. San Francisco, CA, 94109. 

Sincerely, 

Dave Maass 
Director of Investigations 
Electronic Frontier Foundation 

Upload documents directly: https://accounts.muckrock.com/accounts/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.muckrock.com%2Faccounts%2Flogin%2F%3Fnext%3D%252Faccounts%252Fagency_login%252Fchula-vista-police-department-5237%252Fautomated-license-plate-readers-chula-vista-police-department-136414%252F%253Femail%253Dchulavistaca%252540govqa.us&url_auth_token=AAAdsrnh2p3K7C8xBscTbToth7k%3A1ort8W%3AjPXnGx2qgpdvszOD0cRxuI3D-R3dUNUMLVRdLpAVtFQ" 
This request still requires the need to search for, collect, and appropriately examine a number of separate and distinct records that are demanded in a single request; therefore, pursuant to the provisions of Government Code section 6253(c), the City is asserting its authority to extend the time to reply.  This assertion of the City’s authority to extend the time to reply shall not serve as a waiver of any privileges or exemptions to disclosure pursuant to applicable provisions of the CPRA and any other applicable statutory and/or case law authority.  Upon completion of this process, this office will contact you to inform you of any responsive records and the costs associated with obtaining the same. 
In light of the above, this office will respond to your request on or before 12/01/2022 to inform you of when responsive records may be available. Thank you in advance for your patience and anticipated consideration regarding this matter. 
Should you have any questions please feel free to email this response directly. 

Sincerely, 

Police Support Services Staff

title: Incident/Investigation Report Evanston Police Dept

communications.subject: Illinois Freedom of Information Act. Request: Incident/Investigation Report Evanston Police Dept
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the Illinois Freedom of Information Act., I hereby request the following records:

Incident/investigation report for Case #22-009080, ORI IL163200, Deceptive Collection Practice 1185 for victim David A Walker.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

Sincerely,

Michael Molitch-Hou

communications.subject: Your first record request #22-2790 has been opened.
communications.communication:

title: Sustained findings since 2017

communications.subject: North Carolina Public Records Law Request: Sustained findings since 2017
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern:

Pursuant to the North Carolina Public Records Law, I hereby request the following records:

Under the North Carolina Public Records Law, G.S. §132-1.,I am requesting copies of records related to cases of sustained findings of police misconduct at the Internal Affairs of the Fayetteville police department, between 2017 and 2022. This includes, but is not limited to, documents, reports, multimedia, body-worn camera footage, arrest filings, and so on. It also includes all documents, notes, correspondence and memoranda evidencing sustained findings reports and investigations, and all communication and correspondence in whatever tangible medium between the officials, the victims and the overseeing agency. 

I am requesting digital copies of all responsive documents.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. 

Here, misconduct includes, but is not limited to:

Excessive (unreasonable) force – beatings, manhandling of people in handcuffs, improper use of Tasers, injuries inflicted by police dogs, improper use of deadly force, and other police brutality or disregard for the safety of suspects. It also includes, but is not limited to: physical and verbal abuse, restraints happening unreasonably, coerced or forced confessions, and sexual abuse and assault. 

False arrests – pulling over, detention, questioning and searches conducted without any probable cause whatsoever, including cases of planted evidence, racial profiling and trumped-up charges of resisting arrest.

Government records in North Carolina are public in nature unless identified as confidential pursuant to law. The North Carolina Public Records Law, found at N.C.G.S. Chapter 132, which provides that “the public records and public information compiled by the agencies of North Carolina government or its subdivisions are the property of the people.  Therefore, it is the policy of this State that the people may obtain copies of their public records and public information free or at minimal cost unless otherwise specifically provided by law.”
The Law states that public records "shall mean all documents, papers, letters, maps, books, photographs, films, sound recordings, magnetic or other tapes, electronic data-processing records, artifacts, or other documentary material, regardless of physical form or characteristics, made or received pursuant to law or ordinance in connection with the transaction of public business by any agency of North Carolina government or its subdivisions."

Should you have any questions, please do not hesitate to contact me at 415-769-8210 or ananyatiwarijournalism@gmail.com.

The requested documents will be made available to the general public, and this request is not being made for commercial purposes.

In the event that there are fees, I would be grateful if you would inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available or CD-ROM if not.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. I look forward to receiving your response to this request within 10 business days.

Sincerely,

Ananya Tiwari

title: AUBURN SCHOOL DISTRICT - Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) FINAL SUBMISSION, drafts, notes, worksheets, communications, estimates, and working documents for years 2019 - 2021
tags: joint legislative audit and review committee (jlarc)

communications.subject: Washington Public Records Act Request: AUBURN SCHOOL DISTRICT - Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) FINAL SUBMISSION, drafts, notes, worksheets, communications, estimates, and working documents for years 2019 - 2021
communications.communication:
AUBURN SCHOOL DISTRICT - Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) FINAL SUBMISSION, drafts, notes, worksheets, communications, estimates, and working documents for years 2019 - 2021

Via email: lconnors@auburn.wednet.edu

To whom it may concern,

Each state and local agency with at least $100,000 of staff and legal costs associated with fulfilling public records requests in the preceding fiscal year is required to submit a report to the Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC). State and local agencies that spent less than $100,000 may voluntarily submit reports (RCW 40.14.026(5)).

PUBLIC RECORDS REQUEST RCW 42.56

I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production, newest to oldest by year:

1.	Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2021. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

2.	Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2021 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2021.


3.	Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2020. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

4.	Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2020 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2020.


5.	Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2019. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

6.	Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2019 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2019.

RECORDS INSTALLMENTS

If production of responsive records will be completed in multiple installments, please begin by producing records in the numerical order requested by subject matter and year. The most recent public records should be produced first. 

PRODUCTION AND DELIVERY OF ELECTRONIC RECORDS

The use of 3rd party “portals” (Such as GOVQA or NEXTREQUEST) for communication and production of records in response to a public records request is optional for the requestor in the State of Washington. Respectfully we decline to use any 3rd party "portal" system, specifically GOVQA and NEXTREQUEST. Please provide all records electronically via direct email attachment, or via no password, no registration internet cloud-based download link.

Please do not direct or invite us to use, register for, or communicate with your agency via any 3rd party portal including but not limited to FOIAOnline, GovQA, NextRequest, FOIAExpress, JustFOIA FOIADirect, WebForm, or any other commercial 3rd party records portal service.
Please provide all electronic records in their native electronic format. Please do not create new records by printing native electronic files then scanning and re-printing these newly scanned prints for electronic production.

FEES

In the event that there are fees, please inform us of the total charges in advance of fulfilling the request in strict compliance with all provisions of the Washington State Public Records Act.

EXEMPTION LOGS

Please ensure all redactions or exemptions claimed by your agency in the production of responsive records are accompanied by a complete and detailed exemption log noting the valid legal reason for each exemption at each redaction location in the record produced, as well as the specific number of pages if any that your agency redacts or withholds in their entirety. Each redaction should be noted by footnote or by a clear reference to the specific justification for that redaction, and only the minimal exempt portion of any record may be withheld.

COMMERICAL PURPOSE DECLARATION

The Washington State Public Records Act prohibits the disclosure of “lists of individuals” for a commercial purpose (RCW 42.56.070(8)). I declare this public records request is not being made for any commercial purpose whatsoever. Also, this public records request is not being made for a "list of individuals." This declaration satisfies all requirements of RCW 42.56 regarding prohibitions on lists and commercial purposes. No additional commercial purpose declaration will be completed for this public records request. 

The requested documents will be made available to the general public.

Thank you in advance for your anticipated cooperation in this matter. We look forward to receiving your response to this request within 5 business days, as the statute requires.

communications.subject: Confirmation - PRR #2022-111 - MuckRock - JLARC Reporting
communications.communication:
Dear MuckRock,

This email acknowledges Auburn School District’s receipt of your public records request dated November 14, 2022. Specifically, you requested:

AUBURN SCHOOL DISTRICT - Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) FINAL SUBMISSION, drafts, notes, worksheets, communications, estimates, and working documents for years 2019 - 2021



I request the following identifiable public records to be produced in the following order of production, newest to oldest by year:

1. Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2021. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

2. Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2021 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2021.

3. Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2020. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

4. Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2020 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2020.

5. Provide a complete copy of your agency Joint Legislative Audit and Review Committee (JLARC) report submitted by your agency to JLARC for the year 2019. Note: this identifiable record should be an exact copy of the answers submitted to the JLARC Public Records Request Reporting System.

6. Provide complete copies of any and all worksheets, drafts, estimates, notes, and emails related to the completion of your agency’s final 2019 JLARC report and answers to the JLARC website questionnaire submitted for the year 2019.

Pursuant to RCW 42.56.520, the District estimates that it may be able to provide you with documents responsive to your request within thirty (30) business days (December 26, 2022) to determine the need to clarify the intent of the request, to locate and assemble the information requested, to notify third persons or agencies affected by the request, and/or to determine whether any of the information contained in such documents is exempt from public disclosure.

***I should be able to get this information to you quickly.  The email search might take a little longer. I will provide the information as quickly as possible.

To view the procedure and costs associated with Public Records click Board Policy 4040P<https://drive.google.com/open?id=1q0g-_-8x8bM__8Wuj8NkR1x7R5XMUMDU> . Below is a brief summary of potential fees:

  *   Photocopies or printed copies .15 cents per page
  *   Actual cost of mailing or delivery charge, including cost of the shipping container or envelope
  *   Electronic records .10 cents per page for records scanned to an electronic format
  *   Five cents per every 4 electronic files or attachment uploaded to email, cloud-based data storage service, or other means of electronic delivery
  *   Ten cents per gigabyte for the transmission of public records in an electronic format or for the use of District equipment to send the records electronically
  *   Actual cost of any digital storage media or device provided by the District
  *   A customized service charge may be imposed if the District estimates that the request would require the use of information technology expertise to prepare data compilations, or to provide customized electronic access services when such compilations and customized access services are not used by the District for other District purposes. The customized service charge may reimburse the District up to the actual cost of providing the services.
If requested, the District will provide a summary of the applicable charges before fulfilling the request. The requestor will be allowed to revise the request in order to reduce the applicable charges, A deposit of up to ten percent of the estimated costs may be required before processing the request.

The above timeframes are simply estimates and processing your request may take longer than predicted. If you have questions or concerns, feel free to call me at (253) 931-4900.
Sincerely,

Lisa Connors
Public Records and Compliance Coordinator
Auburn School District

D: 253-887-3955
P: 253-931-4900
E: lconnors@auburn.wednet.edu<mailto:lconnors@auburn.wednet.edu>
915 4th Street NE, Auburn, WA 98002
www.auburn.wednet.edu<http://www.auburn.wednet.edu/>

title: Information Pertaining to Montana Veterinarians

communications.subject: Montana Freedom of Information Act Request: Information Pertaining to Veterinary Licensing in Montana
communications.communication:
To Whom It May Concern,

Under the Montana Public Records Act § 2-6-1001 et seq., please accept my request for an opportunity to obtain copies of, or examine public information held by the Montana Department of Labor, Business Standards Division.

This request pertains to all veterinarians licensed by the state of Montana between January 1, 2012 through today’s date of August 31, 2022. Please provide the following information:

    I) The total number of applications to practice veterinary medicine approved for licensing by the Montana Board Of Veterinary Medicine.
        A) Of those approved licenses, the total number that:
            1) Were previously denied a license to practice by the state of Montana or another jurisdiction.
            2) Were previously sanctioned with disciplinary action by the state of Montana or another jurisdiction.
            3) Were reinstated to active status after having their license previously suspended or revoked, as a result of a disciplinary sanction ordered by the Board.
           
    II) The total number for each year requested, of veterinarians possessing an active license to practice in Montana.
       
    III) The total number of complaints received annually by the Department of Labor alleging any form of misconduct by veterinarians, for each year, between January 1, 2012 through today’s date of August 31, 2022.
        A) Of those complaints, the total number for each year, that were:
            1) Administratively closed.
            2) Heard by a Montana Board of Veterinary Medicine Screening Panel.

        B) Of the complaints heard before a Board screening panel, the total number for each year, that were:
            1) Dismissed with prejudice.
            2) Dismissed without prejudice.
            3) Resulted in disciplinary action.
       
    IV) The total number for each year requested, of veterinarians licensed to practice in Montana, and also licensed to practice in another jurisdiction.
       
    V) If a veterinarian that is concurrently licensed in Montana and another jurisdiction(s), is sanctioned with disciplinary action by another jurisdiction’s board of veterinary medicine, is the Montana Board of Veterinary Medicine notified? 
           If so:
        A) Does the other jurisdiction’s disciplinary sanction become part of that veterinarian’s record with the state of Montana?
        B) Is the other jurisdiction’s disciplinary sanction made available to the public through the Montana Licensee Lookup website?
        C) What is the total number, between January 1, 2012 and August 31, 2022, of those veterinarians that have been disciplined by another jurisdiction’s board, while holding an active license to practice in Montana?
            1) Of those veterinarians, the total number for each year, of complaints received alleging misconduct against their Montana license.
                a) Of those complaints, the total number for each year, that were:
                    i) Administratively closed.
                    ii) Heard by a Montana Board of Veterinary Medicine Screening Panel.     
            2) Of the complaints heard before a Board screening panel, the total number for each year, that were:
                a) Dismissed with prejudice.
                b) Dismissed without prejudice.
                c) Resulted in disciplinary action.
           
    VI) Of the total number of veterinarians who, prior to licensing approval by the Board, were previously denied a license to practice by the state of Montana or another jurisdiction:
        A) The total number for each year, that received complaints alleging any form of misconduct.
        B) Of those complaints, the total number for each year, that were:
            1) Administratively closed.
            2) Heard by a Montana Board of Veterinary Medicine Screening Panel.
        C) Of the complaints heard before a Board screening panel, the total number for each year, that were:
            1) Dismissed with prejudice.
            2) Dismissed without prejudice.
            3) Resulted in disciplinary action.
       
    VII) Of the total number of veterinarians who, prior to licensing approval by the Board, were previously sanctioned with disciplinary action by the state of Montana or another jurisdiction:
        A) The total number for each year, that received complaints alleging any form of misconduct.
        B) Of those complaints, the total number for each year, that were:
            1) Administratively closed.
            2) Heard by a Montana Board of Veterinary Medicine Screening Panel.
        C) Of the complaints heard before a Board screening panel, the total number for each year, that were:
            1) Dismissed with prejudice.
            2) Dismissed without prejudice.
            3) Resulted in disciplinary action.
       
    VIII) Of the total number of veterinarians who were reinstated to active status after having their license previously suspended or revoked, as a result of a disciplinary sanction ordered by the Board:
        A) The total number for each year, that received complaints alleging any form of misconduct.
        B) Of those complaints, the total number for each year, that were:
            1) Administratively closed.
            2) Heard by a Montana Board of Veterinary Medicine Screening Panel.
        C) Of the complaints heard before a Board screening panel, the total number for each year, that were:
            1) Dismissed with prejudice.
            2) Dismissed without prejudice.
            3) Resulted in disciplinary action.
               
    IX) The total number for each year, of veterinary licenses that were permanently revoked as a sanctioned disciplinary action ordered by the Montana Board of Veterinary Medicine.

    X) The total number for each year, of complaints received, alleging unlicensed practice of veterinary medicine.
        A) Of those complaints, the total number for each year, that resulted in the Board referring the complaint to a county attorney for criminal prosecution and/or injunctive action.
           
    XI) When a license is no longer active, how long does that licensee’s record remain available for public viewing on the Montana Licensee Lookup website?

Is any of the above data published publicly? If so, please provide a link to any and all publicly available reports containing the data above.

If your department logs complaints in a database, spreadsheet, or other log, a copy of those logs is fine instead.

If your agency does not maintain these public records, please let me know who does, and include the proper custodian's name and address.

If there are any fees for searching or copying these records, please inform me of the total charges in advance of fulfilling my request. I would prefer the request be filled electronically, by e-mail attachment if available, flash drive, or CD-ROM, if not.

The disclosure of the requested information is in the public interest and will be made available to the general public. This request is not being sought for commercial purposes.

If access to the information I am requesting will take longer than a ‘reasonable’ amount of time, please contact me with information about when I might expect copies or the ability to examine the requested records.

If you deny any or all of this request, please cite each specific exemption you feel justifies the refusal to release the information and notify me of the appeal procedures available to me under the law.

Thank you for considering my request.

Sincerely,
Teresa Beck

communications.communication:
Dear Mr. Kirchgasler and Ms. Braden,

Thank you for your response to my request for public information.

You said that “some” of the information I have requested is not gathered by the department. Would you please provide in detail, specifically what you mean by “some”? Would you please provide a list of the information the department does gather?

Upon your recommendation that I would find much of the information I am seeking at the website you directed me to, I visited the site and found that it does not include any of the information in my request. This website is used for individual license verification and/or to request mailing lists of various entities. Maybe there was a mistake with the URL. If so, please send the corrected web address.

Once I’ve had the opportunity to examine what information your department has gathered and made publicly available online, I will proceed with my revised request.

I will wait for your reply, and look forward to hearing from you. Again, I thank you for your assistance.

Sincerely,
Teresa Beck
